rdf:Description.dct:title: Comparison of ΛCDM and Rh = ct with updated galaxy cluster fgas measurements using Bayesian inference
rdf:Description.dct:creator: Kunj Panchal
Shantanu Desai
rdf:Description.dct:description: Journal of High Energy Astrophysics 43 (2024) 15-19. doi:10.1016/j.jheap.2024.06.003

ce:caption.ce:simple-para:
Priors used for the free parameters for ΛCDM and R
h = ct. Except for Ω
m , which exists only in the calculation of D
A in ΛCDM, the same priors were used for both the models and are the same as in MMA22. We did our analyses using two different prior choices for γ 0, γ 1, K 0 and K 1. The second set of priors is denoted by the asterisk.

ja:head.ce:title:
Comparison of ΛCDM and R
h = ct with updated galaxy cluster f
gas measurements using Bayesian inference

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Technology, Hyderabad, Telangana-502284, India
ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Technology, Hyderabad, Telangana-502284, India

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
We use updated gas mass fraction measurements of 44 massive dynamically relaxed galaxy clusters collated in Mantz et al. (2022) to distinguish between the standard ΛCDM model and
R
h
= c t universe. For this purpose, we use Bayesian model selection to compare the efficacy of both these cosmological models given the data. The gas mass fraction is modeled using both cosmology-dependent terms and also astrophysical parameters, which account for the variation with cluster mass and redshift. We used two different prior choices for some of the astrophysical parameters. We find a Bayes factors of 50 and 5 for ΛCDM as compared to
R
h
= c t for these two prior choices. This implies that ΛCDM is favored compared to
R
h
= c t with significance ranging from substantial to very strong.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para:
One such model is the
R
h
= c t universe model, proposed by Melia (2007); Melia and Shevchuk (2012); Melia (2012). Here, the size of the Hubble sphere given by
R
h
( t ) = c t is the same at all times in contrast to the case of the ΛCDM model, where this coincidence is true only at the current epoch, i.e.
R
h
(
t
0
) = c
t
0
. This model has
H ( z ) =
H
0
( 1 + z ) . As a consequence of this, the rate of expansion (
a
˙
) is constant; while the pressure and energy density satisfy an equation of state given by
p = −
ρ
3
, where
ρ =
ρ
D E
+
ρ
M
+
ρ
r
and
p =
p
D E
+
p
M
+
p
r
( Melia, 2015). In this model, the scale factor
a ( t ) ∝ t ( Melia, 2016a). This model has been tested with a whole slew of cosmological observations by Melia and collaborators; such as cosmic chronometers ( Melia and Maier, 2013; Melia and Yennapureddy, 2018), quasar core angular size measurements ( Wan et al., 2019), quasar X-ray and UV fluxes ( Melia, 2019), Type 1a SN ( Melia et al., 2018), strong lensing ( Leaf and Melia, 2018; Melia et al., 2023), BAO ( Melia, 2023a; Melia and López-Corredoira, 2022), FRBs ( Wei and Melia, 2023) and found to be in better agreement compared to ΛCDM model. The
R
h
= c t model can also explain the preponderance of massive galaxies with
z > 10 observed by JWST ( Melia, 2023b). However, other researchers have reached opposite conclusions and have argued that this model is either inconsistent with observations or is not favored compared to ΛCDM ( Shafer, 2015; Bilicki and Seikel, 2012; Lewis et al., 2016; Haridasu et al., 2017; Lin et al., 2018; Hu and Wang, 2018; Tu et al., 2019; Fujii, 2020; Singirikonda and Desai, 2020). However, many of the above works have used BAO and Alcock-Pacynzski measurements to rule out
R
h
= c t models. The BAO measurements are scaled by the size of the sound horizon at the drag epoch,
r
s
, whose calculation implicitly assumes the ΛCDM model ( Melia and Maier, 2013; Melia and Yennapureddy, 2018). The latest model-independent tests done using BAO without assuming a value of
r
s
or
H
0
, based on Lyman- α measurements favor
R
h
= c t over ΛCDM ( Melia, 2023a). Therefore, it is imperative to do the comparison with cosmological observables, which are independent of the underlying theoretical model. In this work, we revisit the question of comparison of ΛCDM and
R
h
= c t using another model-independent probe, viz. gas mass fraction measurements in galaxy clusters. For this purpose, we use updated measurements collated in Mantz et al. (2022) (MMA22 hereafter), to follow-up on similar test previously carried out in Melia (2016b) (M16, hereafter) using three different datasets.

The outline of this manuscript is as follows. We first review the analysis carried out in M16 in Sect. 2. A very brief primer on Bayesian model comparison can be found in Sect. 3. We discuss the latest
f
g a s
data compiled in MMA22 in Sect. 4. Our analysis and results are summarized in Sect. 5. We conclude in Sect. 6.

The key assumption in the above works is that
f
g a s
at the measured overdensity is constant and independent of redshift ( White et al., 1993; Sasaki, 1996; Pen, 1997; Lima et al., 2003). This ansatz has been tested using a large number of simulations over the past two decades. In Kravtsov et al. (2005), it was shown that the cumulative baryon fraction is close to the universal values of
Ω
b
/
Ω
D M
for
r ≥
r
2500
. Battaglia et al. (2013) found a constant gas fraction at
r
500
using simulations having multiple prescriptions for radiative gas dynamics, star formation, and AGN feedback. Then, Planelles et al. (2013) studied the baryon fraction within
R
2500
,
R
500
, and
R
200
by using three different suites of simulations (with each simulation covering a different physical process) of galaxy clusters in the redshift range
0 ⩽ z ⩽ 1 . They found that the baryon fraction is the same for all the three physical processes and has negligible redshift evolution for
R
200
,
R
500
, and
R
2500
. Most recently, Angelinelli et al. (2023) studied the redshift evolution of gas mass fraction using the Magneticum simulations and quantified the evolution using the gas depletion parameter
γ ( z ) ≡
f
g a s
/ (
Ω
b a r
/
Ω
t o t
) . They found that
γ ( z ) shows a lot of scatter between
( 0.5 − 2 )
R
500
for less massive haloes, while for larger radii
> 2
R
500
, it is independent of mass and redshift ( Angelinelli et al., 2023). A large number of works have also done model-independent tests of the redshift evolution of the gas depletion factor (
γ ( z ) ) using observations of X-Ray and Sunyaev-Zeldovich (SZ) selected galaxy clusters at both
r
500
and
r
2500
( Holanda et al., 2017; Holanda, 2018; Zheng et al., 2019; Bora and Desai, 2021c; Holanda et al., 2022). We report a few highlights from these works. For measurements at
r
2500
, no evolution of the gas depletion factor with redshift was found in Holanda et al. (2017); Holanda (2018). However, a mild decrease in the redshift evolution of gas depletion factor was found in some other works ( Zheng et al., 2019; Holanda et al., 2022). The first work did not use direct
f
g a s
from X-ray observations, but used an empirical relation to obtain
f
g a s
. The second work used strong gravitational lensing systems as distance anchors. A model-independent test of the gas depletion factor using two different SZ selected samples (SPT-SZ Chiu et al., 2018 and Planck-ESZ Ade et al., 2011) based on direct X-ray measurements at
r
500
found opposite trends for the two samples and also a strong dependence on the halo mass ( Bora and Desai, 2021c).

M16 applied this formalism to three different
f
g a s
datasets ( LaRoque et al., 2006; Allen et al., 2008; Ettori et al., 2009). The first two of these datasets consist of gas fraction measurements at
R
2500
( LaRoque et al., 2006; Allen et al., 2008), while the third used measurements at
R
500
( Ettori et al., 2009). All the three datasets were separately fit to Eq (1) for both the models using
χ
2
minimization. The
R
h
= c t model has no free parameters, while ΛCDM has 1-2 free parameters (depending on whether one assumes a flat model or not). Both cosmologies were consistent with a constant
f
g a s
ratio. The reduced
χ
2
for ΛCDM and
R
h
= c t were less than one for all the three samples. The efficacy of these models was evaluated using information theoretical techniques such as AIC, BIC, and KIC ( Liddle, 2007; Krishak and Desai, 2020). For all the three datasets the results from BIC favored
R
h
= c t with a likelihood of
∼ 95 % as compared to 5% for ΛCDM. Therefore, M16 argued that the gas mass fraction data favored
R
h
= c t over ΛCDM. However, we note that these information theoretical criteria assume that the posterior distributions are Gaussian or close-to Gaussian, which may not always be satisfied ( Liddle, 2007). Therefore, we shall use Bayesian model comparison techniques for model selection.

To evaluate the significance of one model (
M
2
) as compared to another one (
M
1
), we calculate the Bayes factor (
B
21
) given by:
(4)
B
21
=
∫ P ( D |
M
2

) P (
θ

2
)
d

∫ P ( D |

where
P ( D |

M
2
given the data D and
P (
θ
2
|

2
) denotes the prior on the parameter vector
θ
2
of the model
M
2
. The denominator denotes the same for model
M
1
. The full expression in the numerator and denominator is referred to as Bayesian evidence for each of the two models. If
B
21
is greater than one, then
M
2
is preferred over
M
1
and vice-versa. The significance can be qualitatively assessed depending on the value of the Bayes factor based on the Jeffreys' scale ( Trotta, 2017). Note that unlike the frequentist or information theory based model comparison techniques, Bayesian evidence does not use the best-fit value for the likelihood or posterior, and does not make any assumptions about the posteriors ( Sharma, 2017). Another advantage of Bayesian model comparison is that it does not penalize parameters which are unconstrained by the data unlike information theory techniques ( Liddle, 2007). Therefore, it is the most robust among the different model comparison techniques.

We summarize the dataset used in MMA22 for this analysis, where more details can be found. MMA22 considered 44 clusters with Chandra X-ray observations in the redshift range
0.018 ≤ z ≤ 1.16 . These clusters are dynamically the most relaxed with their intra-cluster medium temperatures ≥ 5 keV. This minimizes any systematic uncertainties related to departures from hydrostatic equilibrium. The gas measurements were obtained in a shell within
( 0.8 − 1.2 )
r
2500
of each cluster. 40 of these clusters were used for previous cosmological studies with
f
g a s
( Mantz et al., 2014), and MMA22 used deeper observations for the same clusters. In addition, four other clusters, viz. Perseus Cluster, RCS J1447+0828, SPT J0615-5746, and SPT J2215-3537 were added to the sample. The total exposure time for these clusters was equal to 4.9 Ms. A tabulated summary of the
f
g a s
measurements for these clusters along with their associated uncertainties can be found in Table 1 of MMA22. Similar to previous works, all the
f
g a s
measurements were tabulated assuming a reference cosmology of
Ω
M
= 0.3 ,
Ω
Λ
= 0.7 and
H
0
= 70 km/sec/Mpc. The X-ray based masses for these clusters have also been compared to weak lensing masses, with their ratio given by
0.96 ± 0.12 ( Applegate et al., 2016), where the error is the quadrature sum of statistical and systematic errors. Therefore, there is no hydrostatic bias for this cluster sample.

Similar to MMA22, our model for the gas mass fraction also includes various astrophysical nuisance parameters in addition to the dependence on cosmology. We use the same parameterization as in MMA22 and is described as follows:
(5)

where
Ω
b
and
Ω
m
are the matter densities. For their values we use measurements from Planck 2020 cosmology, viz.
Ω
m
= 0.315 ± 0.0011 and
Ω
b
= 0.05 ± 0.008 ( Aghanim et al., 2020), which are obtained from a combination of TT, EE and TE angular power spectra (cf. Table 1 of Aghanim et al. (2020)). This ratio is a measure of the baryonic to dark matter density (or the cosmic baryon fraction), which we assume (similar to M16) is independent of redshift for our cluster sample. Note that since this ratio will appear in the expression for both ΛCDM as well as
R h = c t , hence we keep these fixed, even though
Ω
m
and
Ω
b
are prima-facie free parameters within ΛCDM. It might also seem counter-intuitive to use these same values for
R
h
= c t , since it is sometimes stated that this model might not contain dark matter ( Lewis and van Oirschot, 2012). However, as emphasized by Melia and collaborators in multiple works ( Melia, 2015, 2016b; Yennapureddy and Melia, 2021; Melia and Fatuzzo, 2016), the
R
h
= c t model also contains baryonic and dark matter, in addition to dark energy and radiation. The value of
Ω
M
has been estimated to be ≈0.27 ( Melia, 2015). Similarly it was shown that
Ω
b
must satisfy the constraint
0.026 ≲
Ω
b
≲ 0.037 to reconcile with constraints on reionization ( Melia and Fatuzzo, 2016). Furthermore, M16 has stressed that because of Birkhoff's theorem, if
f
g a s
(which is
∝
Ω
b
/
Ω
m
) is constant in ΛCDM, it should be the same in all cosmological models, including
R
h
= c t . Therefore, it is safe to assume that this ratio is constant for
z ≲ 2 as emphasized in M16. Therefore, we can use the Planck 2020 value for the ratio of
Ω
b
to
Ω
m
in Eq. (5) for both the models.

Therefore, the gas depletion factor has an explicit dependence on the halo mass. Such a dependence of the gas fraction on the halo mass has also been found in model-independent estimates of the gas depletion factor in SPT-SZ and Planck ESZ data ( Bora and Desai, 2021c). Finally, we incorporate the cosmology dependence of
f

To calculate the Bayesian evidence for both the models, we use the following Gaussian likelihood:

= c t we use

given in Eq. (2). The priors used for all the free parameters in Eq. (7) are the same as in MMA22 and are summarized in Table 1. Furthermore, we also redid the analysis with Gaussian priors on
K
0
and
γ
0
similar to a recent work, which has used the same data for determination of Hubble constant ( Gonzalez et al., 2024) (See also Barbosa et al., 2024 which used Gaussian prior on
K
0
while doing another cosmological tests using gas mass fraction data). We present our results for both these choice of priors. We note that
R
h
= c t has no cosmology related free parameters, and the only free parameters in this model are the astrophysical nuisance parameters, which are also common to ΛCDM. For the flat ΛCDM model, we have an additional free parameter, namely
Ω
m
, used in calculation of angular diameter distance.

To calculate the Bayesian evidence for both the models, we have the used Dynesty ( Speagle, 2020) package, which is based on the Nested sampling algorithm Ashton et al. (2022). We now present our results.
•
Uniform priors on
K
0
and
γ
0
: When we use the same uniform priors on
K
0
and
γ
0
as in MMA22, the Bayes factor for the flat ΛCDM model compared to
R
h
= c t model is equal to 50. According to Jeffreys' scale ( Kerscher and Weller, 2019) this constitutes “very strong” evidence for flat ΛCDM over
R
h
= c t .
•
Normal priors on
K
0
and
γ
0
: Once again, we calculate the Bayes factors using normal priors on
K
0
∈ N (0.93,0.11) and
γ
0
∈ N (0.79,0.07) similar to Gonzalez et al. (2024). Since we do not get closed contours for
K
1
and
γ
1
, using these normal priors, we use a broader range of priors on
K
1
and
γ
1
given by
K
1
∈ U ( − 0.6 , 0.6 ) and
γ
1
∈ U (-0.6,0.6). With these new priors we find Bayes factor of around 5, which corresponds to substantial evidence in favor of the flat ΛCDM model.

Therefore, even though earlier analysis in M16 favored
R
h
= c t over ΛCDM, updated
f
g a s
measurements at
R
2500
collated in MMA22 seem to favor ΛCDM with very strong or substantial evidence depending on whether uniform or normal priors are used on
K
0
and
γ
0
. Of course, ΛCDM, is still not decisively favored, for which the Bayes factor needs to be greater than 100. In the Appendix, we also apply this procedure to one of the other datasets which used
f
g a s
measurements at
R
2500
( Allen et al., 2008).

A test for the constancy of galaxy cluster gas mass fraction measurements as a function of redshift was implemented in M16 for two different cosmological models, ΛCDM and
R
h
= c t using three different datasets. They found that both the models are consistent with a constant gas mass fraction. However, since the
R
h
= c t model has no free parameters, M16 asserted using BIC based information theory test that
R
h
= c t is favored over ΛCDM with a relative likelihood percentage of 95:5.

Recently, updated gas mass fraction measurements at
R
2500
of one of the samples tested in M16, were presented in MMA22. This sample consists of 44 dynamically relaxed very massive clusters. In this work, we do a similar comparison of the above two cosmological models with these updated gas mass fraction measurements. For this purpose, we use Bayesian model selection and calculate the Bayes factor between these two models to ascertain the best model among the two. Furthermore, we model the gas mass fraction using additional astrophysical nuisance parameters, which account for the dependence on cluster mass and redshift, in addition to the cosmology-dependent terms. We did our analyses with two sets of priors. For the first set, we used the same priors as in MMA22. For the second set we used Gaussian priors on
γ
0
and
K
0
, similar to another recent work ( Gonzalez et al., 2024), whereas MMA22 had used uniform priors for the same. When we use the same priors as MMA22, we find that the Bayes factor for the flat ΛCDM compared to
R
h
= c t is about 50. According to the Jeffreys' scale, this constitutes very strong evidence for the flat ΛCDM over
R
h
= c t . However, when we use Gaussian priors for two astrophysical nuisance parameters
γ
0
and
K
0
, we get a Bayes factor of 5, which corresponds to substantial evidence in favor of ΛCDM. Therefore, we find that the Bayes factors depends on the priors used. However for both the prior choices we find moderate to strong evidence in favor of the flat ΛCDM model over
R
h
= c t . Therefore, we conclude that contrary to M16 the latest gas mass fraction measurements at
r
2500
support ΛCDM over
R
h
= c t .
Kunj Panchal: Formal analysis. Shantanu Desai: Writing – review & editing, Writing – original draft, Supervision, Conceptualization.

ce:conflict-of-interest.ce:para: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: We are grateful to Adam Mantz for clarification about priors used in MMA22 and the anonymous referee for several useful comments and constructive feedback on our manuscript.

ce:section.ce:label: Appendix A
ce:section.ce:para:
We carried out the same analysis done in Sect. 5 to the data given in Allen et al. (2008), which was one of the datasets used in M16 and consists of
f
g a s
measurements at
r
2500
( Allen et al., 2008). This data was obtained by the same team which created the MMA22 dataset. Note however that this dataset has been superseded by the MMA22 dataset. The dataset in Allen et al. (2008) consists of 42 hot dynamically relaxed galaxy clusters with
k
T
2500
> 5 keV observed using Chandra in the redshift range of
0.05 < z < 1.1 with a total exposure time of 1.63 Ms. Out of the 42 clusters in Allen et al. (2008), 29 are common with the data collated in MMA22. The dataset did not provide values for
M
2500
, but listed
r
2500
measurements for each of the clusters. We calculated
M
2500
using the
r
2500
values using the following relation:
(A.1)
M
Δ
=
4 π
3
Δ
ρ
c
( z )
r
3
,
with
Δ = 2500 . Here
ρ
c
( z ) is the critical density at the redshift of the galaxy cluster and corresponds to and r is the radius within which the mean overdensity of cluster is Δ times the critical density. The critical density at a redshift z is given by
(A.2)
ρ
c
( z ) =
3
H
2
( z )
8 π G
We use the same reference cosmology as Allen et al. (2008), which is a flat ΛCDM with
Ω
m
= 0.3 and
H
0
= 70 km/s/Mpc as a reference cosmology to carry out the analysis. We first did our analysis using the same prior as in MMA22 for this data. However, since we could not get closed contours for
K
1
and
γ
1
, we used extended range of uniform priors for these parameters to
U (-1,1). We obtain a Bayes factor of 1.5 for ΛCDM over
R
h
= c t . When we used the same Gaussian priors for
K
0
and
γ
0
as in Gonzalez et al. (2024), we get a Bayes factor of 1.2 Therefore with both prior choices, both the models are equally favored based on Bayesian model comparison and one cannot arbitrate between the two models. Therefore, unlike M16, we do not find any evidence that
R
h
= c t is favored over the flat ΛCDM for the dataset in Allen et al. (2008).
